Award.AwardTitle: EARS: Collaborative Research: Enhancing Spectral Access via Directional Spectrum Sensing Employing 3D Cone Filterbanks: Interdisciplinary Algorithms and Prototypes

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Proposal No. 1247946
Devabhaktuni, Vijaya Kumar

Intellectual Merit
This NSF EARS project proposes a new spectrum sensing architecture combined with joint link scheduling and routing to significantly enhance access to the radio spectrum. Traditional non-directional sensing algorithms do not offer information about the direction of primary and secondary signals, directional information on interference, and information on network node location, and hence significantly limit the potential of cognitive radio technology in terms of spectrum utilization. This project envisions a generalized framework leading to the determination and subsequent utilization of spatio-temporal vacancies in time, frequency, position and direction. New mathematical, hardware, and software algorithms and techniques will be pioneered toward enabling low-complexity digital radios. Multi-dimensional sensed information will drive the innovation of cross-layer link scheduling and routing schemes aimed at boosting the cognitive radio network performance. The proposed innovations will be accomplished through mathematical formulation and modeling of directional sensing algorithms based on multi-dimensional signal processing concepts. The project will also investigate low-complexity fast algorithms for enabling real-time realization leading to new types of (i) digital integrated circuits, (ii) new design techniques for cognitive radios, and (iii) highly agile radio frequency component models all leading to an integrated directional spectrum sensor.

Broader Impacts
This proposal entails tightly integrated research and educational activities at four universities including an HBCU and an undergraduate institution. Spectrum-aware education is pursued as one of the key components of the project because wireless system designers and policy makers alike urgently need this knowledge for pioneering new innovations in this upcoming area of technology. Scientific findings enabled by the proposed research in the cognitive radio networks will serve as a tangible tool-box for engineering transformational technologies such technologies could, in turn, lead to mushrooming of businesses and services that directly benefit from intellectual property (e.g. patents). This research will foster startup firms manufacturing new devices that will potentially improve today's wireless infrastructure. Distinct and diverse applications in education, energy, environment, healthcare, infrastructure, and public-safety will be studied from a unified perspective, i.e. spectrum scarcity, with the objective of maximizing the untapped economic potential of such scientific findings. The project will involve minorities, underrepresented groups, and women in research, while inspiring spectrum-aware educational concepts through new laboratory modules. Participation of underrepresented groups and women will be encouraged and promoted through mentorship and outreach, aimed at inspiring them to take up graduate studies in engineering and computer science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our objective in this research was to develop novel design methodologies to realize microstrip-based front-end components (e.g., antennas, couplers, power dividers) that are commonly used in modern wireless communication systems. The developed radio frequency components of interest exhibit advanced electrical properties such as multiband/wideband functionality without compromising the physical features including circuitry area, structural complexity, fabrication constraints, and above all else, cost. The theory of nonuniform transmission lines accompanied with evolutionary optimization techniques were used to establish the novel concept of impedance-varying transmission lines to achieve the intended performance. Upon verifying the theoretical design approaches analytically, the resulting components were simulated using commercial full-wave simulation tools, fabricated and tested to validate the overall design process.

Our project entailed the realization of novel front-endswith custom-design specifications by varying the width of the signal traces along the propagation path of the electromagnetic wave. Modulation of widths profiles allowed key physical and electrical advantages such as miniaturized circuitry, increased bandwidth, and selective operation. Different configurationswere examined and modified to meet the research goals. Mathematical guidelines were formulated in bounded nonlinear optimization problems, and solved using computer intelligence.

This research trained and delivered electrical engineers not only capable of designing RF/microwave components for the use of modern communications technologies, but also to integrate them to form front-end modules. The research project proposed by the PI had a diverse academic training and scholarly experience. The project fostered intellectual bonding of RF circuitry, wireless communications, microwave engineering, and computer intelligence expertise into one unified paradigm.

The ultimate goal of our research was to develop passive microwave circuitry that is capable of supporting simultaneous frequencies, and thus, enabling emerging solutions to spectrum congestion (e.g., cognitive radios). Hence, the proposed miniaturized schematics have the potential to efficiently utilize the scares bandwidth resources, which in turn benefit publicity by achieving higher transfer rates, welcoming more simultaneous devices to log in, and implementing more convenient wireless communication channels/protocols.

Research methodologies was tuned to the industrial market by developing design algorithms that result in advanced electrical characteristics of grave importance to current and future applications at no expense to circuitry occupation, design complexity, and cost. All novel  components in this research addressed compactness and planarity (i.e., single-layered), and realized inexpensive custom designed front-ends with flexible redefinition electrical capacities and minimum added fabrication constraints (e.g., extra transmission lines, multi-layer structures, packaging and manufacturing).
